title: What is the willing suspension of disbelief in a Shakespeare play? - Quora

response.answer_text: While suspension of disbelief was a concept that came after Shakespeare - so he could not have used the idea - Aristotle wrote about the mechanics of the concept in The Poetics and Shakespeare was most likely well aware of this: A probable impossibility is favourable to an improbable possibility. So we accept that Harry Potter can use a flying broomstick because it is probable with in the world of the story, while completely impossible in reality. Witches flying on broomsticks is favourable to the very real possibility that twins separated at birth or over the adventures of a lifetime can be reunited, but not the improbability that they wouldn’t recognise each other when standing less than 20 feet apart (Comedy of Errors, Twelfth Night). While this is possible, when watching or reading the plays, it is highly improbable - but necessary for the wind up of the plots (flawed as they are). This ‘suspension’ also allows us to believe that Orlando doesn’t recognise Rosaline dressed up as the boy Ganymede in As You Like It or Portia disguised as a layer in The Merchant of Venice - even though the audience does. Probably one of the biggest of these (if you can quantify these things as big or small) is the improbable and impossible ending for The Winter’s Tale, when the dead queen comes in as a statue and is brought back to life. And one of the reasons this one sticks out like a sore thumb is that it doesn't follow a convention that Shakespeare uses with his audiences in all of the plays. In every Shakespeare play, the audience is cast in the role of ‘god.’ The audience always knows more than any character within the world of the play. The audience is directly spoken to by characters who know there is an audience (there was no 4th wall in Elizabethan/Jacobean theatre and none of Shakespeare’s characters talk to themselves - EVER - that is a 19th century convention born out of the weakness of realism). The audience sits in a ‘magic’ realm that does not exist anywhere else in life - save maybe as a congregation in church but a congregation knows less than the ‘actors’ (priests) on their stage (alters) - and Shakespeare put that hallowed, magic place of the audience and their relationship to the actors to great use. But in doing so, he created some wonky scenarios where we have to look past the flawed improbable to see the beauty of his work.

“Suspension of disbelief” is a phrase originating with the Romantic poet, critic, and philosopher Samuel Taylor Coleridge, and it refers to putting quibbles about probability or verisimilitude aside in order to follow where a work of fiction tries to lead us — sometimes violating our sense of “what is likely” to do so. In the fourteenth chapter of his Biographia Literaria, Coleridge was discussing the kinds of Gothic fantasy he explored in works like “The Rime of the Ancient Mariner” and “Christabel,” which he contributed to his and Wordsworth’s landmark book, Lyrical Ballads. Coleridge is recalling discussions from the time that work was being composed and assembled: It was agreed, that my endeavours should be directed to persons and characters supernatural, or at least romantic, yet so as to transfer from our inward nature a human interest and a semblance of truth sufficient to procure for these shadows of imagination that willing suspension of disbelief for the moment, which constitutes poetic faith.[1] Related is what Keats, a Romantic of the succeeding generation, said Shakespeare possessed so enormously—I mean Negative Capability, that is, when a man is capable of being in uncertainties, mysteries, doubts, without any irritable reaching after fact and reason[.][2] So: take these formulations, add Shakespeare, stir. Footnotes[1] from Biographia Literaria, Chapter XIV by Samuel Taylor Coleridge[2] Negative capability - Wikipedia

The term a “willing suspension of disbelief” is actually a Romantic concept first described by the poet Samuel Taylor Coleridge. In his Biographia Literaria, It describes that an author describes such a true to life character that the reader accepts his or reality no matter how fantastic the setting is. Certainly this can be applied to Shakespeare. Both Hamlet and Macbeth are believable characters even if both live in worlds in which ghosts actually make an appearance.

The willing suspension of disbelief for the moment is the phrase that S.T. Coleridge coined to describe the contract between reader and writer. In drama it applies between audience and performer. Fiction is an invitation to play together in an imaginary world for a while. In modern realist style (no true naturalism or realism is fully possible in fiction it should be noted) the audience expects to be convinced that the fiction is as realistic as possible. The parameters for a Shakespearian era play are related but not the same as a modern cinema drama.

There are too many examples to list them all. Art is, by definition, artificial, and we accept that the artifice is part of the serious game when we read a novel, watch a film, look at a painting or go to a play. For example, we know that people don’t speak in iambic pentameters, yet in Shakespeare’s plays many characters do. We willingly suspend our disbelief as we realise we’re watching heightened reality, not reality. The same goes for the richly metaphoric language of the plays. For example, we know that in real life no one would answer a grieving brother who’s just learned that his sister has been drowned, and wants to know where it happened, with a lengthy description of the flowers found on the river bank, as Gertrude does to Laertes in ‘Hamlet’. This just wouldn’t happen in real life, but it’s right in the artificial world of the play because it magnifies the real tragedy of the event. As Touchstone says in ‘As You Like It’, ‘the truest poetry is the most feigning’. In other words, in art, to arrive at the truth you have to tell some big lies.

“O for a Muse of fire, that would ascend The brightest heaven of invention! A kingdom for a stage, princes to act, And monarchs to behold the swellingscene! Then should the warlike Harry, like himself, Assume the port of Mars, and at his heels (Leash’d in, like hounds) should famine, sword, and fire Crouch for employment. But pardon, gentles all, The flat unraised spirits that hath dar’d On this unworthy scaffold to bring forth So great an object. Can this cockpit hold The vasty fields of France? Or may we cram Within this wooden O the very casques That did affright the air at Agincourt? O, pardon! Since a crooked figure may Attest in little place a million, And let us, ciphers to this great accompt, On your imaginary forces work. Suppose within the girdle of these walls Are now confin’d two mighty monarchies, Whose high, upreared, and abutting fronts The perilous narrow ocean parts asunder. Piece out our imperfections with your thoughts; Into a thousand parts divide one man, And make imaginary puissance; Think, when we talk of horses, that you see them Printing their proud hoofs i’ th’ receiving earth; For ’tis your thoughts that now must deckour kings, Carry them here and there, jumping o’er times, Turning th’ accomplishment of many years Into an hour-glass: for the which supply, Admit me Chorus to this history; Who, Prologue-like, your humble patience pray, Gently to hear, kindly to judge, our play.

Well, you’re at a play. There are not that many places where you pay an admission, sit in an audience, and bear witness to fellow human beings wear clothes that aren't theirs, speak sentences (lines) that were written for them, and pretend there are relationships between each other. Oh, and in the case of a Shakespeare play, they are speaking an version of English that hasn't been spoken for around 400 years. You do something at a movie theatre, but there are only images on a screen.
